column6: then
column7: my dear child
column8: ’ said the witch

column18: and at night she got up quietly

column72: and asked:

column1: ‘This is how it happens

column53: at a distance of a yard from one another. Across them she placed the other bones

column1: When her husband
column2: the Pig
column3: came back to his house

column8: and he changed himself into a dove

column13: and her heart beat with fear

column15: in her great joy she forgot all her sufferings
column16: and they seemed as nothing to her. He was a very handsome man
column17: as straight as a fir tree. They sat down together and she told him all her adventures
column18: and he wept with pity at the tale. And then he told her his own history.‘I am a King’s son. Once when my father was fighting against some dragons
column19: who were the scourge of our country

column21: who was a witch

column23: I was forced to remain a Pig for three more years. Now that we have suffered for each other
column24: and have found each other again
column25: let us forget the past.’Next morning they set out early to return to his father’s kingdom. Great was the rejoicing of all the people when they saw him and his wife; his father and his mother embraced them both
column26: and there was feasting in the palace for three days and three nights.And as the King was old and had no heirs
column27: he put them on the throne in his place. And they ruled as only kings rule who have suffered many things. And if they are not dead they are still living and ruling happily.[8] Once upon a time there lived a King and Queen. They had three sons
column28: two of them with their wits about them

column30: devouring some of the animals every night. The King did all he could
column31: but he was unable to destroy it. So at last he called his sons together and said
column32: ‘Whoever will destroy the Norka

column34: the eldest son undertook the task. As soon as it was night
column35: he took his weapons and set out. But before he reached the park
column36: he went into a traktir (or tavern)
column37: and there he spent the whole night in revelry. When he came to his senses it was too late; the day had already dawned. He felt himself disgraced in the eyes of his father
column38: but there was no help for it. The next day the second son went
column39: and did just the same. Their father scolded them both soundly
column40: and there was an end of it.

column1: Well

column5: and went straight into the park

column8: and the Norka came rushing up

column11: leapt to his feet
column12: crossed himself

column1: Once upon a time there were a man and a woman
column2: who had an only daughter. Now it happened that one of their sheep went astray
column3: and they set out to look for it
column4: and searched and searched
column5: each in a different part of the wood. Then the good wife met a witch
column6: who said to her:The man thought the witch was really his wife
column7: and he did not know that his wife was the sheep; so he went home with her
column8: glad at heart because his sheep was found. When they were safe at home the witch said to the man:Shortly after this they took the black sheep from the flock and slaughtered it. The witch made pease-soup of it
column9: and set it before the daughter. But the girl remembered her mother’s warning. She did not touch the soup
column10: but she carried the bones to the edge of the field and buried them there; and there sprang up on the spot a birch tree—a very lovely birch tree.Some time had passed away—who can tell how long they might have been living there?—when the witch
column11: to whom a child had been born in the meantime
column12: began to take an ill-will to the man’s daughter
column13: and to torment her in all sorts of ways. And so they drove into the King’s feast all the outcasts
column14: and the maimed
column15: and the halt
column16: and the blind. In the good man’s house
column17: too

column19: and the poor girl stayed at home and wept. She tried to be sure to pick up the grains of barley
column20: but she soon saw how useless her labour was; and so she went in her sore trouble to the birch tree on her mother’s grave
column21: and cried and cried

column23: and say to her:‘Do not weep
column24: ’ said her mother consolingly. ‘Break off one of my branches
column25: and strike the hearth with it crosswise
column26: and all will be put right.’ The girl did so. She struck the hearth with the birchen branch

column29: dry herself on another

column31: she had grown so lovely that no one on earth could rival her. Splendid clothing was given to her
column32: and a horse
column33: with hair partly of gold
column34: partly of silver
column35: and partly of something more precious still. The girl sprang into the saddle
column36: and rode as swift as an arrow to the palace. As she turned into the courtyard of the castle the King’s son came out to meet her
column37: tied her steed to a pillar
column38: and led her in. He never left her side as they passed through the castle rooms; and all the people gazed at her

column41: and thinking it was a dog

column5: hastily unfastening her horse from the pillar

column11: washed herself on one side of it and dried herself on the other; and this time still finer clothes were given to her
column12: and a very beautiful steed. She broke off a branch of the birch tree

column14: so that the seeds flew into the pot
column15: and then hastened to the castle.Again the King’s son came out to meet her

column17: and led her into the banqueting hall. At the feast the girl sat next him in the place of honour
